poem:
**Hidden Menace**

Beneath the soil, silence hums,  
a buried whisper where children run.  
Footsteps dance on a fragile thread,  
where ghosts of yesterday have bled.  
Innocence skips, unaware of fate,  
marked by rust, in dormant hate.  
2025, a hoped-for dawn,  
yet the quiet detonation lingers on.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Guardian view on the return of landmines: a deadly peril resurges | Editorial Eleven years ago, members of the Ottawa treaty banning the use, production, stockpiling and transfer of antipersonnel mines agreed a deadline for completing their obligations: 2025. The ambitious timeline reflected the immense progress made since the pact was signed in 1997. Back then, 25,000 people were killed or injured each year by landmines; by 2013, that number had fallen to 3,300. Tens of millions". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
